head.title: Extensive Active-Site Formation in Trirutile CoSb2O6 by Oxygen Vacancy for Oxygen Evolution Reaction in Anion Exchange Membrane Water Splitting | ACS Energy Letters

meta.content: Extensive Active-Site Formation in Trirutile CoSb2O6 by Oxygen Vacancy for Oxygen Evolution Reaction in Anion Exchange Membrane Water Splitting

Here, we first report an octahedral Co2+-rich Co oxide with inactive Sb5+ ion as an oxygen evolution reaction (OER) electrocatalyst for efficient H2 production by lowering the cell voltage in anion exchange membrane water splitting (AEMS). To enhance the OER activity of Co-based oxides, it is crucial to increase the amount of Co4+ at OER potential, known as the fast OER active site. Using in situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy, we observed most of the octahedral Co2+ in trirutile CoSb2O6 oxidized to Co3+ before the OER potential. Furthermore, oxygen vacancies facilitated further oxidation from Co3+ to Co4+ by tuning OH– adsorption energy of Co and then produced extensive active sites for O–O bond formation in OER compared to spinel-type Co3O4. As a result, we obtained a much lower OER overpotential of 360 mV at 100 mA/cm2, providing 88% of the highest H2 energy efficiency in the AEMS by applying a cell voltage of 1.7 V.

div.span: Supporting Info (1)
SUBJECTS:

div.p:
Here, we first report an octahedral Co
2+
-rich Co oxide with inactive Sb
5+
ion as an oxygen evolution reaction (OER) electrocatalyst for efficient H
2
production by lowering the cell voltage in anion exchange membrane water splitting (AEMS). To enhance the OER activity of Co-based oxides, it is crucial to increase the amount of Co
4+
at OER potential, known as the fast OER active site. Using
in situ
X-ray absorption spectroscopy, we observed most of the octahedral Co
2+
in trirutile CoSb
2
O
6
oxidized to Co
3+
before the OER potential. Furthermore, oxygen vacancies facilitated further oxidation from Co
3+
to Co
4+
by tuning OH
–
adsorption energy of Co and then produced extensive active sites for O–O bond formation in OER compared to spinel-type Co
3
O
4
. As a result, we obtained a much lower OER overpotential of 360 mV at 100 mA/cm
2
, providing 88% of the highest H
2
energy efficiency in the AEMS by applying a cell voltage of 1.7 V.

Electrochemical water splitting is one of the promising methods to directly obtain high-purity hydrogen from aqueous media. The oxygen evolution reaction (OER) on the anode is the rate-determining step owing to the sluggish kinetics and high overpotential,
(1,2)
which leads to reducing the energy efficiency of the hydrogen generation. Unlike proton exchange membrane water splitting, the conventional alkaline water-splitting system applying a simple porous diaphragm has long been commercialized owing to the possibility of large-scale build-up, despite the relatively low purity of hydrogen.
(3)
Recently, anion exchange membrane water splitting (AEMS) has been considered as an alternative method because of its capability of producing hydrogen of high purity (up to 99.999%) and the availability of iron-triad element-based catalysts because of their thermodynamic stability in alkaline media.
(4,5)
Nevertheless, most studies focus only on the overpotential or stability at low current densities, such as 10 mA cm
–2
, which is insufficient for practical application. To obtain sufficient hydrogen production rates, the current density of a typical water electrolyzer is 300–400 mA cm
–2
with a cell voltage between 1.7 and 2.4 V.
(6)

Cobalt oxide groups such as spinel,
(7)
perovskite,
(8)
layered hydroxide,
(9)
and oxyhydroxide
(10)
are being vigorously studied as OER electrocatalysts. Among them, the spinel-type Co
3
O
4
, which contains one Co
2+
in the tetrahedral site (Co
2+
-Td) and two Co
3+
ions in the octahedral site (Co
3+
-Oh), exhibits outstanding OER performance in alkaline media and has been actively investigated.
(11−13)
Although Co
4+
ion is the real OER active site, it was revealed that the adjacent Co
3+
-Oh plays a key role in promoting fast OER kinetics.
(14)
However, only near-surface Co
3
O
4
could be oxidized into an amorphous CoO
x
(OH)
y
accompanied by a change from Co
2+
-Td to Co
3+
-Oh.
(15)
Therefore, it is necessary to investigate both the conversion behavior of Co
2+
-Oh and Co
2+
-Td to Co
3+
-Oh and accessibility
(16)
and adjacency
(17)
of Co
3+
-Oh for a high population of Co
3+
-Oh. Besides, the incorporation of oxygen vacancies in Co oxide can not only provide more surface-active sites but also finely tune the electronic structure to promote reactant adsorption.
(18−20)
However, the role of oxygen vacancies in Co-based catalysts has not been fully understood in terms of which OER step can be affected by oxygen vacancies. Herein, we successfully synthesized oxygen-deficient trirutile CoSb
2
O
6
onto Ni foam by a straightforward binder-free sol–gel method to enhance the population of Co
3+
-Oh. Trirutile structure (AB
2
O
6
), a replicated unit cell of rutile structure (AO
2
) along the
c
axis,
(21)
contains octahedral A
2+
ions surrounded by six O atoms.
(22)
We aimed at identifying the role of Co
2+
-Oh and oxygen vacancy of CoSb
2
O
6
introduced by OER inactive Sb. Using
in situ
X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) analysis, we observed great Co oxidation state change in CoSb
2
O
6
for Co
4+
formation, known as OER active site, compared to spinel-type Co
3
O
4
. Additionally, the potential performance of AEMS application as an anode catalyst was first identified.
(23−26)

The structure of the as-prepared CoSb
2
O
6
catalyst on Ni foam was characterized by both Grazing Incident X-ray diffraction (GI-XRD) and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD).
Figure
1
a shows three intense 2θ peaks from Ni foam, but a 2θ peak related to the crystalline phase containing Co or Sb oxide did not arise because of the low crystalline structure. In
Figure
1
b, three broad peaks at 28, 32, and 53
o
from CoSb
2
O
6
powder, avulsed from the substrate, were shown and matched with the pattern of the trirutile CoSb
2
O
6
reference. Furthermore, with increasing annealing temperature for CoSb
2
O
6
, the full-width half-maximum of the 2θ peaks narrowed because of crystallization (
Figure S1
).
(27)
Raman spectra, providing information about symmetries from metal–oxygen bonding, show three peaks at 521, 656, and 725 cm
–1
, which can be found in the CoSb
2
O
6
phase according to previous studies
(21,28)
(
Figure
1
c). Hence, the crystal structure of as-prepared CoSb
2
O
6
on Ni foam is based on a trirutile CoSb
2
O
6
structure, and the Co atom in CoSb
2
O
6
exists as Co
2+
in an octahedral geometry with six O atoms.
(22)
In the case of the XRD patterns of the Co
3
O
4
, it perfectly matched the XRD pattern of the Co
3
O
4
spinel structure (
Figure S2
).
(29)
Using scanning electron microscopy (SEM), we confirmed the morphology of the CoSb
2
O
6
cluster on Ni foam as a barnacle-like shape due to its tails and pores, which could contribute to increasing the electrochemical surface area (ECSA)
(30)
(
Figure
1
d). As shown in
Figure
1
e, the distribution of Co and Sb atoms, confirmed by energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) in high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images, was highly uniform in the CoSb
2
O
6
cluster. The TEM image shows one CoSb
2
O
6
cluster without lattice from the crystal structure, and the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern in this area shows vague ring patterns (
Figure
1
f,g), indicating an amorphous structure. By contrast, the circular shape of Co
3
O
4
clusters were formed on Ni foam, and it has a clear lattice from the cobalt spinel structure (
Figure S3
).

Figure 1. (a) GI-XRD pattern of CoSb
2
O
6
(■ peaks are due to Ni foam), (b) PXRD pattern of CoSb
2
O
6
powder with the CoSb
2
O
6
reference, and (c) Raman spectra of CoSb
2
O
6
. (● indicates the bond symmetry from CoSb
2
O
6
structure.) (d) SEM images of CoSb
2
O
6
. (e) HRTEM/EDS mapping with O K-edge, Co K-edge, and Sb L-edge. (f) TEM image of CoSb
2
O
6
with (g) SAED pattern.

Although iron-triad element catalysts undergo a change in oxidation state during the OER, we performed X-ray photon spectroscopy (XPS) analysis to compare the initial oxidation states in Co of Co
3
O
4
and CoSb
2
O
6
; the Co 2p spectra were deconvoluted with Co
3+
, Co
2+
, and satellite peaks in
Figure
2
a.
(18)
Corresponding with the structure of Co
3
O
4
and CoSb
2
O
6
from XRD and Raman, Co
3
O
4
has both Co
3+
and Co
2+
oxidation states in Co 2p
3/2
and Co 2p
1/2
, whereas the majority of Co atoms in CoSb
2
O
6
are present as Co
2+
ions.
(31)
The O
w
peak at 532.6 eV is related to OH species of adsorbed water molecules, and the O
L
peak at 529.7 eV is due to the oxygen atoms-bound metal atom in the metal oxide.
(32)
The O
V
peak at 531.2 eV results from defect sites with low oxygen coordination, referred to as oxygen vacancies.
(33)
The higher O
V
peak area of CoSb
2
O
6
in
Figure
2
b indicates that it possessed more oxygen vacancies than Co
3
O
4
. Because the Sb 3d orbital overlaps with O 1s, we also conducted electron spin resonance (ESR) analysis to confirm whether the O
V
peak results from the oxygen vacancies. In
Figure
2
c, only CoSb
2
O
6
shows one ESR signal at
g
= 2.003, which results from electron trapping on the oxygen vacancies,
(34)
but not that of Co
3
O
4
. Interestingly, the ESR signal was not observed in other CoSb
2
O
6
fabricated at higher annealing temperatures (525 and 725 °C) (
Figure S4
). This implies that the prerequisite for the formation of oxygen vacancies is not only Sb introduction into the Co lattice but also insufficient annealing temperature. The surface oxygen in the trirutile CoSb
2
O
6
could not be fully oxidized and crystallized because of the moderate annealing temperature; hence, a portion of the surface oxygen could evacuate from the CoSb
2
O
6
lattice and generate oxygen vacancies.

Figure 2. XPS spectra in (a) Co 2p and (b) O 1s orbital of (lower) CoSb
2
O
6
and (upper) Co
3
O
4
. The spectra include raw data (dots) and deconvoluted peaks (shaded area). (c) ESR spectra of (i) CoSb
2
O
6
and (ii) Co
3
O
4
.

Before addressing the OER activity of CoSb
2
O
6
and Co
3
O
4
, the change in the Co redox behavior was observed by repeating CV cycles. A
1
(1.05–1.3 V
RHE
) and A
2
(1.4–1.55 V
RHE
) represent the oxidation peaks of Co
2+
/Co
3+
and Co
3+
/Co
4+
, and the large wave of approximately 1.1–1.5 V represents the reduction peak of Co
4+
/Co
3+
.
(16,29,35)
Although the initial Co oxidation state in CoSb
2
O
6
is Co
2+
, it is typically hard to observe the A
1
peak on a Ni foam because of capacitive and Faradaic currents from the substrate.
(15,16,36)
Upon the repetitive CV cycles up to 10 cycles in
Figure
3
a, the A
1
peak height was reduced while the A
2
peak grew up, indicating irreversible oxidation of the Co
2+
-Oh site to form Co
3+
species. Further changes in A
1
and A
2
peaks were negligible after the 10th cycles. Moreover, the OER activity (judged by overpotential @ 100 mA/cm
2
) of CoSb
2
O
6
gradually increased concomitantly. To clarify the A
1
peak by ruling out the effects of Ni foam, we collected CV curves for CoSb
2
O
6
powder catalyst directly coated on the glass carbon and observed the reduction of A
1
peak during 10 cycles more clearly (
Figure S6
). By contrast, there was no change in both A
1
(related to the oxidation of the Co
2+
-Td site of spinel Co
3
O
4
) and A
2
peaks (
Figure
3
b). After CV cycling, CoSb
2
O
6
maintained their own structure without surface CoO
x
formation or phase segregation of Co, and an increased fraction of lattice oxygen in XPS spectra in O 1s suggests that the oxygen vacancy might stabilize the Co
3+
to prevent its reduction back into the Co
2+
(
Figure S7
). To understand how the evolution of Co
3+
/Co
4+
redox peaks affects the OER activity, we compared the amount of Co
4+
atom and turnover of frequency (TOF) in
Figure
3
c (the calculation method is presented in the
Supporting Information
). For CoSb
2
O
6
, the electrochemically active surface area monotonically increased up to the sixth cycle after which the TOF was dramatically improved from 0.11 to 0.41 s
–1
in the 10th cycle
.
(TOFs at various potentials are in
Figure S8
.) The active site density and intrinsic OER activity of the Co
3
O
4
were virtually constant and always lower than those of CoSb
2
O
6
. The overpotential values at 100 mA/cm
2
for CoSb
2
O
6
and Co
3
O
4
in the backward CV scan were 360 and 460 mV, respectively (
Figure
3
d). The OER activity of CoSb
2
O
6
at 100 mA/cm
2
of current density was stably maintained for 120 h, demonstrating great stability in the alkaline environment (
Figure
3
e). The enhanced OER activity of CoSb
2
O
6
after 10 cycles would be attributed not only to the extension of electroactive Co
4+
from Co
2+
-Oh oxidation but also to the enhanced intrinsic activity of Co atoms. Because the Tafel slope (which can provide an insight into the reaction mechanism
(37)
) was also reduced during the CV cycling for CoSb
2
O
6
(
Figure
3
f), we speculate that the improved intrinsic activity of Co atoms (above the sixth cycle) could be related to the kinetics of OH
–
adsorption. After the 10th CV cycle, the Tafel slope of Co
3
O
4
was near 120 mV/dec (
Figure
3
g), which implies that the first reaction step (M + OH
–
→ M–OH
ads
+ e
–
) among four-electron reactions could be the rate-determining step (RDS).
(38,39)
This result is in accord with other Co-based catalysts, which have sluggish OH
–
adsorption because of their low oxophilicity and the ability to adsorb OH
–
and inhibit the related reaction progression in the nature of Co.
(40−42)
Meanwhile, CoSb
2
O
6
showed 46 mV/dec of Tafel slope, which indicates that OH
–
adsorption in the first reaction step was not the RDS in CoSb
2
O
6
. Interestingly, the values are close to those from most of the previous studies focused on the oxygen vacancies in metal oxide catalysts (∼40 mV/dec).
(18,33,34,43)
In the Co-based OER catalyst, Co
4+
ion from Co
3+
/Co
4+
oxidation is known as the active site for O–O formation in oxygen generation, because Co
4+
increases the electrophilicity of the adsorbed O from OH
–
, which contributes to the formation of O–OH by the nucleophilic attack and promotes the deprotonation of −OOH.
(44)
Namely, the superior OER activity of CoSb
2
O
6
could result from accelerating the kinetics of Co
4+
formation because of fast OH
–
adsorption by oxygen vacancies in CoSb
2
O
6
. Moreover, with increasing scan rate in 85%
iR
-compensated CVs, the Co
3+
/Co
4+
oxidation peak potential was positively shifted for Co
3
O
4
because of the electrochemically irreversible oxidation to Co
4+
,
(45)
while the peak potentials were constant for CoSb
2
O
6
conforming to a Nernstian reversibility (
Figure S9a,b
).
(46−48)

Figure 3. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) results of (a) CoSb
2
O
6
and (b) Co
3
O
4
in N
2
-saturated 1 M KOH at a scan rate of 10 mV/s with a rotating speed of 1600 rpm with respect to the number of cycles [(i) 1, (ii) 2, (iii) 5, and (iv) 10 cycles]. A
1
indicates the Co
2+
/Co
3+
oxidation peak, and A
2
means Co
3+
/Co
4+
oxidation peak. (c) The number of Co
4+
atoms and TOF (
j
@1.65 V
RHE
) of each CV cycle. (d) CV curves with (inset) enlarged backward LSV for overpotential determination at 100 mA/cm
2
at a scan rate of 5 mV/s after CV 10 cycles. (e) Chronopotentiogram (CP) at 100 mA/cm
2
of CoSb
2
O
6
as stability test. (f) Tafel slopes of each CV cycle. (g) Tafel plot (log(
j
)
vs iR
-free backward CV) after CV 10 cycles of (i) CoSb
2
O
6
(R = 6.6 Ω), (ii) Co
3
O
4
(
R
= 6.0 Ω, which is impedance value at 100 kHz in
Figure S5
).

In situ
XANES analysis at the Co K-edge was performed to observe the change in the Co oxidation state during OER. The edge position, the energy at 50% intensity of the Δμ
0
(
E
0
), in XANES is sensitive to the metal oxidation state; thus, it could be an indicator of the oxidation state of the metal.
(40)
Figure
4
a,b shows XANES in the Co K-edge of CoSb
2
O
6
and Co
3
O
4
at open-circuit potential (OCP), pre-OER (1.4 V
RHE
), and OER (<3 mA/cm
2
). There is a linear relationship in the edge positions of various Co-based oxides;
(49)
thus, we obtained the linear regression with the reference Co materials as shown in
Figure S10
. The edge positions of Co
2+
, Co
3+
, and Co
4+
were found at 7717.9, 7721.9, and 7723.0 eV, respectively. The inset of
Figure
4
a indicates Co atoms in CoSb
2
O
6
underwent oxidation from Co
2.3+
to Co
3+
upon increasing applied potential from OCP to pre-OER, corresponding to previous studies.
(40,50,51)
Co
2+
-Oh in trirutile CoSb
2
O
6
almost fully converted to Co
3+
, corresponding to previous CV analysis. At the OER potential, the Co atoms oxidized to Co
3.8+
, reaching the edge position at 7722.9 eV. Because the oxidation of Co
3+
to Co
4+
is a limitation in Co-based oxide, the considerable shift toward the edge position for Co
4+
could be attributed to the accumulation of a high population of Co
4+
intermediates, which was generated by the facile Co
3+
/Co
4+
oxidation.
(14,41,52)
The increased metal oxidation state during OER in acid was also observed in trirutile MnSb
2
O
6
in an
ex situ
XAFS.
(53)
However, the Co atoms in Co
3
O
4
showed a limited increment of Co oxidation state from Co
2.8+
at OCP to Co
3.1+
in the OER (
Figure
4
b).
In
situ
XANES evidence was previously provided that only near-surface Co
3
O
4
could be oxidized into an amorphous CoO
x
(OH)
y
,
(15)
which might lead to the small shift of the Co oxidation state. After the extension of the amount of Co
3+
atoms through the irreversible Co
2+
-Oh/Co
3+
-Oh oxidation in the case of the CoSb
2
O
6
system, the oxygen vacancy allows fast and complete conversion of Co
3+
-Oh to Co
4+
, the real OER active site (
Figure
4
c). Because the oxygen vacancies in CoSb
2
O
6
can complement the low oxophilicity of Co and improve OH
–
adsorption kinetics, the intrinsic activity of electroactive Co
3+
for OER could be improved. The feasibility test of the developed CoSb
2
O
6
OER catalyst in practical water splitting was carried out using an AEM-based zero-gap cell configuration (
Figure
4
d). For sufficient hydrogen production rate, alkaline water electrolysis generally operates at a constant current density of approximately 400 mA/cm
2
.
(6)
In
Figure
4
e, CoSb
2
O
6
showed impressive current density, 800 mA cm
–2
at 1.9 V of cell voltage. With increasing current density, the difference in the cell voltage between Co
3
O
4
and CoSb
2
O
6
becomes more significant, which results from not only high intrinsic OER activity but also facile mass charge transfer. Besides the overpotential of the anodes, the ohmic loss owing to catalyst resistance
(54)
and bubble growth
(55)
would significantly contribute to the cell voltage under the elevated operational current density,

which resulted in the AEMS performance being lower than that expected from the RDE results. (

.) We measured the H

are the highest among the three anodes. The maximum H

was 18.7 cm

/min at 1.7 V cell voltage. To compare the H

Considering that the commercial alkaline water electrolyzers have relatively low energy efficiency between 55% and 79%,

In summary, CoSb
2
O
6
was successfully deposited on Ni foam via a binder-free sol-gel method for OER in alkaline media. Owing to OER inactive Sb and insufficient annealing temperature, CoSb
2
O
6
grew as a partially crystalline trirutile structure consisting of Co
2+
-Oh and oxygen vacancies. Prior to the OER, most of the Co
2+
-Oh atoms were irreversibly oxidized to Co
3+
. The oxygen vacancy in CoSb
2
O
6
improved the OH
–
adsorption kinetics by tuning the low oxophilicity of the Co atom, and it facilitated the further complete oxidation of Co
3+
to the OER real active site Co
4+
by reaching a higher Co oxidation state than spinel-type Co
3
O
4
. The synergetic effect of abundant Co
2+
-Oh and oxygen vacancies contributed to enhanced OER activity and AEMS performance. Our study suggests a Co-based trirutile structure as an alkaline OER catalyst, which can widen the range of catalyst candidates for studying the unique catalytic behavior in various electrochemical reactions.

Song, Fang; Bai, Lichen; Moysiadou, Aliki; Lee, Seunghwa; Hu, Chao; Liardet, Laurent; Hu, Xile

A review. Water splitting is the essential chem. reaction to enable the storage of intermittent energies such as solar and wind in the form of hydrogen fuel. The oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is often considered as the bottleneck in water splitting. Though metal oxides had been reported as OER electrocatalysts more than half a century ago, the recent interest in renewable energy storage has spurred a renaissance of the studies of transition metal oxides as Earth-abundant and nonprecious OER catalysts. This Perspective presents major progress in several key areas of the field such as theor. understanding, activity trend, in situ and operando characterization, active site detn., and novel materials. A personal overview of the past achievements and future challenges is also provided.

Qin, Fan; Zhao, Zhenhuan; Alam, Md. Kamrul; Ni, Yizhou; Robles-Hernandez, Francisco; Yu, Luo; Chen, Shuo; Ren, Zhifeng; Wang, Zhiming; Bao, Jiming

We report the development of an efficient and earth-abundant catalyst for electrochem. overall water splitting. Trimetallic NiFeMo alloy is synthesized by hydrothermal deposition from inorg. precursors and subsequent low-temp. thermal annealing. A complete cell made of NiFeMo electrodes on nickel foam exhibits a low voltage of 1.45 V at 10 mA/cm2 as a result of low overpotentials for both hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). High-resoln. transmission electron microscopy reveals that nanometer-sized single-crystal domains of Ni, Fe, and Mo are intimately integrated at the at. level, which enables a synergistic effect of metallic Ni, Fe, and Mo for efficient HER, while self-formed Ni-Fe-Mo (oxy)hydroxides on the surface of the NiFeMo anode become active sites for OER. Such a multimetallic alloy and its (oxy)hydroxides represent a typical HER/OER catalyst couple, and our method provides a new route to develop efficient low-cost metallic alloys for overall water splitting.

A review on the fundamental and technol. issues relevant to H2O electrolysis in alk. and proton exchange membrane (PEM) devices is given. Due to price and limited availability of the Pt group metal (PGM) catalysts they currently employ, PEM electrolyzers have scant possibilities of being employed in large-scale H prodn. The importance and recent advancements in the development of catalysts without PGMs are poised to benefit more the field of alk. electrolysis rather than that of PEM devices. This paper presents the authors' original data which demonstrate that an advanced alk. electrolyzer with performances rivaling those of PEM electrolyzers can be made without PGM and with catalysts of high stability and durability. Studies on the advantages/limitations of electrolyzers with different architectures do show how a judicious application of pressure differentials in a recirculating electrolyte scheme helps reduce mass transport limitations, increasing efficiency and power d.

Helical cobalt borophosphates to master durable overall water-splitting
Menezes, Prashanth W.; Indra, Arindam; Zaharieva, Ivelina; Walter, Carsten; Loos, Stefan; Hoffmann, Stefan; Schloegl, Robert; Dau, Holger; Driess, Matthias
Energy & Environmental Science

The sustainable electrochem. prodn. of hydrogen from water is a key element in the transition toward carbon-neutral energy systems. Application at a global scale requires the discovery of precious metal-free electrocatalysts that unify high energetic efficiency, long-term stability and economic viability. Here we report the striking properties of noble metal-free, alkali-metal cobalt borophosphates acting as robust and efficient materials for bi-functional electrocatalytic water-splitting to give hydrogen and oxygen. Alkali-metal cobalt borophosphates are porous cryst. inorg. materials with chiral DNA-like helical structures bearing two chem. distinct types of water mols., coordinated and strands of hydrate water assocd. via hydrogen bonds, located in the channels, which are predestined to possess superior catalytic performance. Depending on the applied electrode potential, they can be reversibly switched between catalysis of the hydrogen and oxygen evolution reactions, both at low overpotentials. This bifunctionality provides access to technol. simple overall water-splitting systems with energetic efficiencies exceeding the 75% level (above 90% based on a higher heating value) and uncompromised long-term stability, now verified with a two-and-a-half month period.

A review. Ionic sepn. and recombination processes in water electrolysis and fuel cell devices are of equal importance as the electron transfer processes that occur at the electrode surfaces. We illustrate the basic thermodn. concepts governing the flow of ions in electrolyzer and fuel cell systems and the effects of pH gradients on the electrochem. phenomena. Particularly, we focus on the use of bipolar membranes, which are composed of anion- and cation-selective membranes enabling operation with different pH environments at the anode vs. the cathode. The use of bipolar membranes thus broadens the materials' availability and could enable low-cost electrolysis systems that operate at very high efficiency. We end by discussing different materials and highlighting key gaps needed to realize such a system.

Water electrolysis has the potential to become a key element in coupling the electricity, mobility, heating and chem. sector via Power-to-Liqs. (PtL) or Power-to-Gas (PtG) in a future sustainable energy system. Based on an extensive market survey, discussions with manufacturers, project reports and literature, an overview of the current status of alk., PEM and solid oxide electrolysis on the way to large-scale flexible energy storage is presented. These main water electrolysis technologies were compared in terms of available capacity, nominal and part-load performance, flexibility (load range, load gradients, start-up time, stand-by losses) lifetime and investment costs. This review provides a basis of the parameters required and the necessary understanding of electrolysis fundamentals and technologies for a techno-economic anal. of water electrolysis-based concepts and an evaluation of PtG and PtL in energy system studies.

Wu, Tianze; Sun, Shengnan; Song, Jiajia; Xi, Shibo; Du, Yonghua; Chen, Bo; Sasangka, Wardhana Aji; Liao, Hanbin; Gan, Chee Lip; Scherer, Gunther G.; Zeng, Lin; Wang, Haijiang; Li, Hui; Grimaud, Alexis; Xu, Zhichuan J.

The development of efficient and low-cost electrocatalysts for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is crit. for improving the efficiency of water electrolysis. Here, we report a strategy using Fe substitution to enable the inactive spinel CoAl2O4 to become highly active and superior to the benchmark IrO2. The Fe substitution is revealed to facilitate surface reconstruction into active Co oxyhydroxides under OER conditions. It also activates deprotonation on the reconstructed oxyhydroxide to induce neg. charged oxygen as an active site, thus significantly enhancing the OER activity of CoAl2O4. Furthermore, it promotes the pre-oxidn. of Co and introduces great structural flexibility due to the uplift of the oxygen 2p levels. This results in the accumulation of surface oxygen vacancies along with lattice oxygen oxidn. that terminates as Al3+ leaches, preventing further reconstruction. We showcase a promising way to achieve tunable electrochem. reconstruction by optimizing the electronic structure for low-cost and robust spinel oxide OER catalysts.

The efficiency of many energy storage technologies, such as rechargeable metal-air batteries and H prodn. from H2O splitting, is limited by the slow kinetics of the O evolution reaction (OER). Ba0.5Sr0.5Co0.8Fe0.2O3-δ (BSCF) catalyzes the OER with intrinsic activity that is at least an order of magnitude higher than that of the state-of-the-art Ir oxide catalyst in alk. media. The high activity of BSCF was predicted from a design principle established by systematic examn. of >10 transition metal oxides, which showed that the intrinsic OER activity exhibits a volcano-shaped dependence on the occupancy of the 3d electron with an eg symmetry of surface transition metal cations in an oxide. The peak OER activity was predicted to be at an eg occupancy close to unity, with high covalency of transition metal-O bonds.

We report a type of NiCoFe layered triple hydroxides (LTHs) supported on carbon fiber cloth (CFC) (NiCoFe LTHs/CFC) as high-performance electrocatalysts for overall water splitting in alk. media. The NiCoFe LTHs/CFC as an oxygen evolution reaction (OER) electrocatalyst shows excellent catalytic activity and durability, such as low overpotential of ∼239 mV at 10 mA/cm2, small Tafel slope of ∼32 mV/dec and conservation rate of catalytic activity (∼99%) after 12 h of continuous electrolysis at 20 m/cm2. As a hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) electrocatalyst, NiCoFe LTHs/CFC also shows low onset potential, small Tafel slope, and superior durability. The NiCoFe LTHs/CFC-based overall water splitting exhibits a low onset potential (∼1.51 V), a low splitting potential (∼1.55 V) at 10 mA/cm2, and excellent durability, and the performance is comparable to that of IrO2/Pt-based overall water splitting. This work will open a new avenue toward the development of high-performance and inexpensive layered triple hydroxides electrocatalysts.

Moysiadou, Aliki; Lee, Seunghwa; Hsu, Chia-Shuo; Chen, Hao Ming; Hu, Xile

The oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is the performance-limiting half reaction of water splitting, which can be used to produce hydrogen fuel using renewable energies. Whereas a no. of transition metal oxides and oxyhydroxides have been developed as promising OER catalysts in alk. medium, the mechanisms of OER on these catalysts are not well understood. Here we combine electrochem. and in situ spectroscopic methods, particularly operando X-ray absorption and Raman spectroscopy, to study the mechanism of OER on cobalt oxyhydroxide (CoOOH), an archetypical unary OER catalyst. We find the dominating resting state of the catalyst as a Co(IV) species CoO2. Through oxygen isotope exchange expts., we discover a cobalt superoxide species as an active intermediate in the OER. This intermediate is formed concurrently to the oxidn. of CoOOH to CoO2. Combing spectroscopic and electrokinetic data, we identify the rate-detg. step of the OER as the release of dioxygen from the superoxide intermediate. The work provides important exptl. fingerprints and new mechanistic perspectives for OER catalysts.

Electrochemical Synthesis of Spinel Type ZnCo2O4 Electrodes for Use as Oxygen Evolution Reaction Catalysts
Kim, Tae Woo; Woo, Myong A.; Regis, Morrisa; Choi, Kyoung-Shin

A new electrochem. synthesis route was developed to prep. spinel-type ZnCo2O4 and Co3O4 as high quality thin film-type electrodes for use as electrocatalysts for oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Whereas Co3O4 contains Co2+ in the tetrahedral sites and Co3+ in the octahedral sites in the spinel structure, ZnCo2O4 contains only Co3+ in the octahedral sites; Co2+ in the tetrahedral sites is replaced by Zn2+. Therefore, by comparing the catalytic properties of ZnCo2O4 and Co3O4 electrodes prepd. with comparable surface morphologies and thicknesses, it was possible to examine whether Co2+ in Co3O4 is catalytically active for OER. The electrocatalytic properties of ZnCo2O4 and Co3O4 for OER in both 1 M KOH (pH 13.8) and 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7) solns. were investigated and compared. The results suggest that the Co2+ in Co3O4 is not catalytically crit. for OER and ZnCo2O4 can be a more economical and environmentally benign replacement for Co3O4 as an OER catalyst.

The fabrication and design of earth-abundant and high-performance catalysts for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) are very crucial for the development and commercialization of sustainable energy conversion technologies. Although spinel catalysts have been widely explored for the electrochem. oxygen evolution reaction (OER), the role of two geometrical sites that influence their activities has not been well established so far. Here, more effective cobalt-zinc oxide catalysts are presented for the OER than classical Co3O4. Interestingly, the significantly higher catalytic activity of ZnCo2O4 than that of Co3O4 is somewhat surprising since both crystallize in the spinel-type structure. The reasons for the latter remarkable difference of ZnCo2O4 and Co3O4 could be deduced from structure-activity relationships of the bulk and near-surface of the catalysts using comprehensive electrochem., microscopic and spectroscopic techniques with a special emphasis on the different roles of the coordination environment of metal ions (octahedral vs. tetrahedral sites) in the spinel lattice. The vital factors influencing the catalytic activity of ZnCo2O4 over Co3O4 could be directly attributed to the higher amt. of accessible octahedral Co3+ sites induced by the preferential loss of zinc ions from the surface of the ZnCo2O4 catalyst. The enhanced catalytic activity is accompanied by a larger d. of metal vacancies, defective sites and hydroxylation. The results obtained here clearly demonstrate how a surface structural modification and generation of defects of catalysts can enhance their OER performance.

In any artificial photosynthetic system, the oxidn. of water to mol. oxygen provides the electrons needed for the redn. of protons or carbon dioxide to a fuel. Understanding how this four-electron reaction works in detail is important for the development of improved robust catalysts made of Earth-abundant materials, like first-row transition-metal oxides. Here, using time-resolved Fourier-transform IR spectroscopy and under reaction conditions, we identify intermediates of water oxidn. catalyzed by an abundant metal-oxide catalyst, cobalt oxide (Co3O4). One intermediate is a surface superoxide (three-electron oxidn. intermediate absorbing at 1,013 cm-1), whereas a second obsd. intermediate is attributed to an oxo Co(IV) site (one-electron oxidn. intermediate absorbing at 840 cm-1). The temporal behavior of the intermediates reveals that they belong to different catalytic sites. Knowledge of the structure and kinetics of surface intermediates will enable the design of improved metal-oxide materials for more efficient water oxidn. catalysis.

Water splitting catalyzed by earth-abundant materials is pivotal for global-scale prodn. of non-fossil fuels, yet our understanding of the active catalyst structure and reactivity is still insufficient. Here we report on the structurally reversible evolution of cryst. Co3O4 electrocatalysts during oxygen evolution reaction identified using advanced in situ X-ray techniques. At electrode potentials facilitating oxygen evolution, a sub-nanometer shell of the Co3O4 is transformed into an X-ray amorphous CoOx(OH)y which comprises di-μ-oxo-bridged Co3+/4+ ions. Unlike irreversible amorphizations, here, the formation of the catalytically-active layer is reversed by re-crystn. upon return to non-catalytic electrode conditions. The Co3O4 material thus combines the stability advantages of a controlled, stable cryst. material with high catalytic activity, thanks to the structural flexibility of its active amorphous oxides. We propose that cryst. oxides may be tailored for generating reactive amorphous surface layers at catalytic potentials, just to return to their stable cryst. state under rest conditions.

Efficient catalysts for the anodic oxygen evolution reaction (OER) are crit. for electrochem. H2 prodn. Their design requires structural knowledge of their catalytically active sites and state. Here, we track the at.-scale structural evolution of well-defined CoOx(OH)y compds. into their catalytically active state during electrocatalytic operation through operando and surface-sensitive X-ray spectroscopy and surface voltammetry, supported by theor. calcns. We find clear voltammetric evidence that electrochem. reducible near-surface Co3+-O sites play an organizing role for high OER activity. These sites invariably emerge independent of initial metal valency and coordination under catalytic OER conditions. Combining expts. and theory reveals the unified chem. structure motif as μ2-OH-bridged Co2+/3+ ion clusters formed on all three-dimensional cross-linked and layered CoOx(OH)y precursors and present in an oxidized form during the OER, as shown by operando X-ray spectroscopy. Together, the spectroscopic and electrochem. fingerprints offer a unified picture of our mol. understanding of the structure of catalytically active metal oxide OER sites.

The clean energy carrier, hydrogen, if efficiently produced by water electrolysis using renewable energy input, would revolutionize the energy landscape. It is the sluggish oxygen evolution reaction (OER) at the anode of water electrolyzer that limits the overall efficiency. The large spinel oxide family is widely studied due to their low cost and promising OER activity. As the distribution of transition metal (TM) cations in octahedral and tetrahedral site is an important variable controlling the electronic structure of spinel oxides, the TM geometric effect on OER is discussed. The dominant role of octahedral sites is found exptl. and explained by computational studies. The redox-active TM locating at octahedral site guarantees an effective interaction with the oxygen at OER conditions. In addn., the adjacent octahedral centers in spinel act cooperatively in promoting the fast OER kinetics. In remarkable contrast, the isolated tetrahedral TM centers in spinel prohibit the OER mediated by dual-metal sites. Furthermore, various spinel oxides preferentially expose octahedral-occupied cations on the surface, making the octahedral cations easily accessible to the reactants. The future perspectives and challenges in advancing fundamental understanding and developing robust spinel catalysts are discussed.

Electrochem. water splitting is a clean technol. for H2 fuels, but greatly hindered by the slow kinetics of the oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Herein, a series of spinel-structured nanosheets with oxygen deficiencies and ultrathin thicknesses were designed to increase the reactivity and the no. of active sites of the catalysts, which were then taken as an excellent platform for promoting the water oxidn. process. Theor. investigations showed that the oxygen vacancies confined in the ultrathin nanosheet could lower the adsorption energy of H2O, leading to increased OER efficiency. As expected, the NiCo2O4 ultrathin nanosheets rich in oxygen vacancies exhibited a large c.d. of 285 mA cm-2 at 0.8 V and a small overpotential of 0.32 V, both of which are superior to the corresponding values of bulk samples or samples with few oxygen deficiencies and even higher than those of most reported non-precious-metal catalysts. This work should provide a new pathway for the design of advanced OER catalysts.

Co3O4, which is of mixed valences Co2+ and Co3+, has been extensively investigated as an efficient electrocatalyst for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER). The proper control of Co2+/Co3+ ratio in Co3O4 could lead to modifications on its electronic and thus catalytic properties. Herein, we designed an efficient Co3O4-based OER electrocatalyst by a plasma-engraving strategy, which not only produced higher surface area, but also generated oxygen vacancies on Co3O4 surface with more Co2+ formed. The increased surface area ensures the Co3O4 has more sites for OER, and generated oxygen vacancies on Co3O4 surface improve the electronic cond. and create more active defects for OER. Compared to pristine Co3O4, the engraved Co3O4 exhibits a much higher c.d. and a lower onset potential. The specific activity of the plasma-engraved Co3O4 nanosheets (0.055 mA/cm2BET at 1.6 V) is 10 times higher than that of pristine Co3O4, which is contributed by the surface oxygen vacancies.

Electrochem. splitting of water to oxygen and hydrogen using earth-abundant first-row transition metal-based catalysts is a promising approach for sustainable energy conversion. Herein, a new convenient synthesis is presented of copper nitride (Cu3N) that acts as a bifunctional electro(pre)catalyst for oxygen evolution reaction (OER), hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), and overall water electrolysis in alk. media. Strikingly, the electrophoretically deposited Cu3N on nickel foam (NF) displayed extremely low overpotentials for both OER and HER, and the overall water splitting cell potential was merely 1.62 V with a remarkable durability of over 10 days. Most notably, the coordinatively unsatd. Cu in Cu3N transformed in situ under a reducing environment and in an oxidative environment into a copper-rich shell that serves as the active site over an equally important elec. conductive Cu3N core to drive proficient catalysis. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report on copper nitride for efficient and durable alk. water electrolysis.

CoSb2O6 was investigated by using neutron diffraction and magnetic susceptibility techniques. The structure found was tetragonal, of the trirutile type, with space group P42/mm, a 4.6495(2), c 9.2763(6) Å. Low-temp. neutron data gave no evidence of structural change down to 20 K. Susceptibility data showed a deviation from Curie-Weiss behavior below 100 K and a max. at 35 K assocd. with low-dimensional ordering. A Curie-Weiss law fit of the data above 100 K gave μeff = 4.62(1) μg and θ = -32.4(3) K. The ordered magnetic structure as detd. by neutron diffraction was indexed on a supercell (2a, a, 2c) and is similar to that found previously for FeTa2O6. Measured magnetic moments below Tc gave an extrapolated zero-temp. moment of 3.3(2) μg for Co2+ and crit. parameters β = 0.12(2) and Tc = 12.64(5) K, consistent with the two-dimensional Ising model. The crystal structure of CoTa2O6 was found to be the same as that for CoSb2O6 with a 4.7358(3), c ..1708(7) Å and with no structural change down to 10K. At 4.2 K magnetic reflections were obsd. that could be indexed with a propagation vector k0 = (1/4, 1/4, 1/4). A two-cone axis helical spin structure is proposed which can account for the obsd. intensities. Some of the differences in magnetic properties of the two compds. can be understood in terms of bond distances within the Co-O layers.

The electrochem. oxidn. of water to oxygen gas is the primary counter reaction to the formation of hydrogen gas via water splitting. In acidic media, the only well-established and active oxygen evolution catalysts are expensive noble metal oxides such as IrOx and RuOx, necessitating the development of practical oxygen evolution catalysts that are stable in acidic media. In this study, stoichiometric, phase-pure CoSb2O6 and MnSb2O6 electrodes are prepd. using electrochem. synthesis and investigated their ability to oxidize water in 0.5 M H2SO4 (pH 0.3). In addn., their stabilities during the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) were carefully examd. by comparing their morphologies, crystallinities, compns., and surface compns. before and after the OER. The chlorine evolution reaction on CoSb2O6 and MnSb2O6 in acidic media was also examd. so that their performances can be compared with previously reported non-stoichiometric CoSb2O6 and MnSb2O6 electrodes. The electrochem. properties and stabilities of stoichiometric, phase-pure CoSb2O6 and MnSb2O6 reported in this study can provide useful insights into the development and understanding of acid-stable, non-noble metal oxide-based OER catalysts.

Water oxidn. is a required half-reaction for electrochem. water splitting. To date, the only well-established active oxygen-evolution catalysts stable under operating conditions and at rest in acidic aq. media contain Ru or Ir, two of the scarcest non-radioactive elements on Earth. We report herein a nickel-manganese antimonate electrocatalyst with a rutile-type crystal structure that requires an initial voltammetric overpotential of 672 ± 9 mV to catalyze the oxidn. of water to O2(g) at a rate corresponding to 10 mA cm-2 of c.d. when operated in contact with 1.0 M sulfuric acid. The chlorine-evolution reaction (CER) is a common, com. valuable electrochem. reaction, and is practiced at industrial scale globally. A precious metal solid soln. of RuO2 or IrO2 with TiO2 is the predominant electrocatalyst for the CER. Herein we report that materials comprised only of non-precious metal elements, specifically cryst. transition-metal antimonates (TMAs) such as NiSb2Ox, CoSb2Ox, and MnSb2Ox, are moderately active, stable catalysts for the electrochem. oxidn. of chloride to chlorine under conditions relevant to the com. chlor-alkali process. Specifically, CoSb2Ox exhibited a galvanostatic potential of 1.804 V vs. NHE at 100 mA cm-2 of Cl2(g) prodn. from aq. pH = 2.0, 4.0 M NaCl after 250 h of operation. Studies of the bulk and surface of the electrocatalyst and the compn. of the electrolyte before and after electrolysis indicated minimal changes in the surface structure and intrinsic activity of CoSb2Ox as a result of Cl2(g) evolution under these conditions.

Nanostructured CoSb2O6 microspheres were prepd. by a colloidal method using cobalt nitrate, SbCl3 and n-dodecylamine in Et alc. Microwave radiation, with a power of ∼160 W, was applied for solvent evapn. The full evapn. was reached after a non-continuous radiation for 200 s. The resulting material was then heated at 200° in static air. At this temp., a large no. of microspheres with smooth surface were formed. The calcination at 700° produced single-phase nanostructured CoSb2O6 hollow microspheres. The surface nanoparticles had an av. particle size of 38 nm. The gas sensing properties of CoSb2O6 thick films were investigated at 400°. The d.c. measurements showed resistance variations (ΔR) of ≈130 Ω in CO2 and ≈75 Ω in O2. In a previous work, these values were 450 and 180 Ω, resp., corresponding to CoSb2O6 prepd. by a soln.-polymn. method. Even though a decrease in ΔR was recorded in the present study, more stable measurements in carbon dioxide were obtained, with lower resistance values. The polarization curves showed a large non-ohmic behavior, with a significant ability to detect variations in the concn. of CO2 and O2. A.c. was also used to characterize the gas sensing properties of CoSb2O6. The measurements in a.c. revealed better repeatability in gas detection and also the capability to detect variations in the gas concn.

Development of efficient, affordable electrocatalysts for the oxygen evolution reaction and the oxygen redn. reaction is crit. for rechargeable metal-air batteries. Here we present lithium cobalt oxide, synthesized at 400 °C (designated as LT-LiCoO2) that adopts a lithiated spinel structure, as an inexpensive, efficient electrocatalyst for the oxygen evolution reaction. The catalytic activity of LT-LiCoO2 is higher than that of both spinel cobalt oxide and layered lithium cobalt oxide synthesized at 800 °C (designated as HT-LiCoO2) for the oxygen evolution reaction. Although LT-LiCoO2 exhibits poor activity for the oxygen redn. reaction, the chem. delithiated LT-Li1-xCoO2 samples exhibit a combination of high oxygen redn. reaction and oxygen evolution reaction activities, making the spinel-type LT-Li0.5CoO2 a potential bifunctional electrocatalyst for rechargeable metal-air batteries. The high activities of these delithiated compns. are attributed to the Co4O4 cubane subunits and a pinning of the Co3+/4+:3d energy with the top of the O2-:2p band.

A review. Electrodes in galvanic and electrolytic energy cells are complicated structures comprising redox-active materials, ionic/electronic conductors, and porous pathways for mass transfer of reactants. In contrast to breakthroughs in component development, methods of optimizing whole-system architectural design to draw max. output have not been well explored. In this Minireview, we introduce generalized types of electrode architecture, discuss fabrication strategies, and characterize already built structures. Systematic efforts to discover optimal electrode configurations will resolve long-standing discrepancies that arise between whole systems and the sums of their parts for a no. of electrochem. reactions and technologies.

Co oxides are known to be active and stable alternative anode electrocatalysts possessing the potential to replace the best performing but most expensive Ir and Ru oxides in alk. H2O electrolysis. Of late, Co oxides loaded on various C supports are reported as a way to outperform Ir or Ru catalysts by improving the use efficiency. The authors introduce Co and Fe nanoparticles embedded C nanofibers (CoFe-CNFs), fabricated through electrospinning and pyrolysis of a polymer mixed with Co and Fe precursors. This method is a facile route for simultaneously making Co and Fe nanoparticles as well as the stable accommodation of the CoFe nanoparticles in the C support. The authors demonstrate the potential of the CoFe-CNFs as active and stable electrocatalysts for the O evolution reaction (OER) in alk. media. The authors conducted detailed physicochem. characterizations to elucidate the effect of the CNFs on the OER activity and stability of the CoFe-CNFs. Probably the CNFs are a medium in which OER-active CoFe alloy nanoparticles are formed homogeneously, and C layers surrounding the nanoparticles are beneficial to the stability of the CoFe-CNFs in the OER.

In Co3O4 systems, the oxygen vacancy is reported to improve the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) activity because of higher Co2+/Co3+ surface ratio. In situ studies have revealed Co3+-site reducibility as the key factor for OER activity of cobalt oxide-based systems. In this context, the OER activity of two Co3O4 systems; c-Co3O4 with higher oxygen defects or Co2+/Co3+ ratio and n-Co3O4 with relatively less Co2+/Co3+ ratio but more Co3+ reducibility are synthesized and analyzed. The systems, n- and c-Co3O4 show overpotential of 380 and 440 mV at 10 mA/cm2 and Tafel slope of 153 and 53 mV/dec, resp., for OER. Electrochem. characterization reveals that the lowering of OER onset potential is influenced by Co3+ reducibility rather than defects in Co3O4 systems while adsorption capacitance arising from surface irregularities, pores and their geometry, and Co3+-Oh sites cause an increase in the Tafel slope values or decrease in OER kinetics. The correlation of the key factors such as Co3+ reducibility and oxygen defects of two different Co3O4 systems toward OER activity can aid the designing of highly efficient cobalt oxide-based OER catalysts.

There is still an ongoing effort to search for sustainable, clean and highly efficient energy generation to satisfy the energy needs of modern society. Among various advanced technologies, electrocatalysis for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) plays a key role and numerous new electrocatalysts have been developed to improve the efficiency of gas evolution. Along the way, enormous effort has been devoted to finding high-performance electrocatalysts, which has also stimulated the invention of new techniques to investigate the properties of materials or the fundamental mechanism of the OER. This accumulated knowledge not only establishes the foundation of the mechanism of the OER, but also points out the important criteria for a good electrocatalyst based on a variety of studies. Even though it may be difficult to include all cases, the aim of this review is to inspect the current progress and offer a comprehensive insight toward the OER. This review begins with examg. the theor. principles of electrode kinetics and some measurement criteria for achieving a fair evaluation among the catalysts. The second part of this review acquaints some materials for performing OER activity, in which the metal oxide materials build the basis of OER mechanism while non-oxide materials exhibit greatly promising performance toward overall water-splitting. Attention of this review is also paid to in situ approaches to electrocatalytic behavior during OER, and this information is crucial and can provide efficient strategies to design perfect electrocatalysts for OER. Finally, the OER mechanism from the perspective of both recent exptl. and theor. investigations is discussed, as well as probable strategies for improving OER performance with regards to future developments.

Insight on Tafel slopes from a microkinetic analysis of aqueous electrocatalysis for energy conversion
Shinagawa Tatsuya; Garcia-Esparza Angel T; Takanabe Kazuhiro
Scientific reports
(
2015
),
5
(
),

.
Microkinetic analyses of aqueous electrochemistry involving gaseous H2 or O2, i.e., hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR), oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER), are revisited. The Tafel slopes used to evaluate the rate determining steps generally assume extreme coverage of the adsorbed species (θ≈0 or ≈1), although, in practice, the slopes are coverage-dependent. We conducted detailed kinetic analyses describing the coverage-dependent Tafel slopes for the aforementioned reactions. Our careful analyses provide a general benchmark for experimentally observed Tafel slopes that can be assigned to specific rate determining steps. The Tafel analysis is a powerful tool for discussing the rate determining steps involved in electrocatalysis, but our study also demonstrated that overly simplified assumptions led to an inaccurate description of the surface electrocatalysis. Additionally, in many studies, Tafel analyses have been performed in conjunction with the Butler-Volmer equation, where its applicability regarding only electron transfer kinetics is often overlooked. Based on the derived kinetic description of the HER/HOR as an example, the limitation of Butler-Volmer expression in electrocatalysis is also discussed in this report.

The electrocatalytic oxygen evolution reaction (OER) presents the key transformation in electrochem. water-splitting majorly detg. energy efficiency and economics of hydrogen generation. In this study, the kinetics of the OER over Ni-Co oxide structured by KIT-6 templating and non-structured Ni-Co oxide catalysts in alk. soln. have been investigated aiming for insight with regard to the resp. kinetically relevant surface reactions. Steady-state Tafel plot anal. and electrochem. impedance spectroscopy (EIS) were used to det. kinetic parameters, Tafel slopes and the order of reaction. A dual Tafel slope behavior was obsd. for both catalysts. Tafel slopes of ca. 40 and 120 mV dec-1 and 90 and 180 mV dec-1 at low and high overpotentials appear for structured and non-structured Ni-Co oxide, resp. A reaction order of unity was obsd. for structured Ni-Co oxide, while non-structured Ni-Co oxide possessed a fractional reaction order in the high overpotential region. The kinetics of OER over structured Ni-Co oxide were governed by Langmuir adsorption with the rate-limiting step after primary adsorption of surface intermediates. In contrast, non-structured Ni-Co oxide obeyed the Temkin adsorption isotherm condition with the primary adsorption step being rate-limiting.

Co-based oxides are suitable electrode materials for the electrocatalytic O evolution reaction (OER) with promising activity and stability, in addn. to being widely available and relatively cheap. The authors study OER on Co3O4(001) and β-CoOOH (011-2) surfaces using d. functional theory calcns. (DFT). The authors construct surface Pourbaix diagrams and study the theor. overpotential for the elementary steps involved in OER on these surfaces. Inclusion of the Hubbard-U correction to DFT (DFT+U) is necessary to recover exptl. obsd. trends in the activity for the strongly correlated Co oxides. The inclusion of the Hubbard-U correction lowers the activity of both Co3O4(001) and β-CoOOH(011-2) when compared to results from pure DFT. The Hubbard-U correction shifts the location of Co3O4 and β-CoOOH from the strong binding leg to the weak binding leg of the OER volcano plot. The calcns. also suggest that the theor. overpotentials for Co3O4 and β-CoOOH are very nearly the same. The authors ascribe this to a similar local coordination environment of the active Co site in Co3O4 and CoOOH under OER conditions.

The authors have studied Li intercalation into two nanoparticulate anode materials for Li ion batteries, Nb-doped TiO2 (Nb-TiO2) and Li4Ti5O12 (LTO), by scan rate-dependent cyclic voltammetry. The av. particle size is 7 nm for Nb-TiO2 and 6 nm for LTO, resp. For both materials, the authors observe a transition in the scan rate dependence of the charge flow, from Li intercalation capacity control at low scan rates to diffusion/phase transformation control at higher scan rates. The peak current densities exhibit an approx. power law dependence on the scan rate with exponents between 0.54 and 0.64, even for low scan rates at which the charge flow is close to the Li intercalation capacity. Also, the authors have tested a method proposed in the literature for differentiating between faradaic and pseudocapacitive charge storage from scan rate-dependent cyclic voltammograms. The obtained results are not phys. meaningful, in particular the obtained neg. pseudocapacitive and faradaic currents. The authors analyzed the origin of these results, and iso-potential plots of the scan rate-dependent current are not suitable for differentiating between faradaic and pseudocapacitive processes.

Espinoza, Eli M.; Clark, John A.; Soliman, Joey; Derr, James B.; Morales, Maryann; Vullev, Valentine I.

What is the best approach for estg. std. electrochem. potentials, E(0), from voltammograms that exhibit chem. irreversibility. The lifetimes of the oxidized or reduced forms of the majority of known redox species are considerably shorter than the voltammetry acquisition times, resulting in irreversibility and making the answer to this question of outmost importance. Halfwave potentials, E(1/2), provide the best exptl. obtainable representation of E(0). Due to irreversible oxidn. or redn., however, the lack of cathodic or anodic peaks in cyclic voltammograms renders E(1/2) unattainable. Therefore, we evaluate how closely alternative potentials, readily obtainable from irreversible voltammograms, est. E(0). Our anal. reveals that, when E(1/2) is not available, inflection-point potentials provide the best characterization of redox couples. While peak potentials are the most extensively used descriptor for irreversible systems, they deviate significantly from E(0), esp. at high scan rates. Even for partially irreversible systems, when the cathodic peak is not as pronounced as the anodic one, the half-wave potentials still provide the best ests. for E(0). The importance of these findings extends beyond the realm of electrochem. and impacts fields, such as materials engineering, photonics, cell biol., solar energy engineering and neuroscience, where cyclic voltammetry is a key tool.

For the prodn. of nonfossil fuels, H2O oxidn. by inexpensive Co-based catalysts is of high interest. Films for the electrocatalysis of H2O oxidn. were obtained by oxidative self-assembly (electrodeposition) from aq. solns. contg., apart from Co, either K, Li or Ca with either a phosphate, acetate or chloride anion. X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) at the Co K-edge revealed clusters of edge-sharing CoO6 octahedra in all films, but the size or structural disorder of the Co-oxido clusters differed. Whereas K binding is largely unspecific, CaCo3O4 cubanes, which resemble the CaMn3O4 cubane of the biol. catalyst in oxygenic photosynthesis, may form, as suggested by XAS at the Ca K-edge. Cyclic voltammograms in a K phosphate buffer at pH 7 revealed that no specific combination of anions and redox-inactive cations is required for catalytic H2O oxidn. However, the anion type modulates not only the size (or order) of the Co-oxido clusters, but also electrodeposition rates, redox potentials, the capacity for oxidative charging, and catalytic currents. On these grounds, structure-activity relations are discussed.

The question of whether the metal chalcogenides (phosphides) that were acknowledged to be efficient materials for bifunctional electrocatalysts really perform as the active species or just "pre-catalysts" was debated. Herein, a series of operando measurements, including in situ x-ray absorption spectroscopy, liq.-phase TEM, and in situ Raman spectroscopy, were conducted to unravel in real time the structural and chem. stability of P-substituted CoSe2 electrocatalysts under both hydrogen and oxygen evolution reactions (HER and OER, resp.) in an alk. electrolyte. It can be conclusively revealed that, in an alk. electrolyte, the P-substituted CoSe2 electrocatalyst was acting as the "pre-catalyst" rather than the real reactive species. The introduction of phosphorus is speculated to generate more vacancies or defects around Co cations in the initial CoSe2 and considerably facilitates the structural transformation into the "real reactive species", such as metallic cobalt (for HER) and cobalt oxyhydroxide (for OER).

The oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is a crit. component of industrial processes such as electrowinning of metals and the chlor-alkali process. It also plays a central role in the development of a renewable energy field for generation a solar fuels by providing both the protons and electrons needed to generate fuels such as H2 or reduced hydrocarbons from CO2. To improve these processes, it is necessary to expand the fundamental understanding of catalytically active species at low overpotential, which will further the development of electrocatalysts with high activity and durability. In this context, performing exptl. investigations of the electrocatalysts under realistic working regimes (i.e., under operando conditions) is of crucial importance. Here, we study a highly active quinary transition-metal-oxide-based OER electrocatalyst by operando ambient-pressure XPS and x-ray absorption spectroscopy performed at the solid/liq. interface. We observe that the catalyst undergoes a clear chem.-structural evolution as a function of the applied potential with Ni, Fe, and Co oxyhydroxides comprising the active catalytic species. While CeO2 is redox inactive under catalytic conditions, its influence on the redox processes of the transition metals boosts the catalytic activity at low overpotentials, introducing an important design principle for the optimization of electrocatalysts and tailoring of high-performance materials.

Strong acid electrolytes are desirable for many implementations of these technologies, although the deployment of such device designs is often hampered by the lack of non-precious-metal oxygen evolution electrocatalysts, with Ir-based oxides comprising the only known catalysts that exhibit stable activity at low overpotential. During our exploration of the Mn-Sb-O system for precious-metal-free electrocatalysts, we discovered that Mn can be incorporated into the rutile oxide structure at much higher concns. than previously known, and that these Mn-rich rutile alloys exhibit great catalytic activity with current densities exceeding 50 mA cm-2 at 0.58 V overpotential and catalysis onset at 0.3 V overpotential. While this activity does not surpass that of IrO2, Pourbaix anal. reveals that the Mn-Sb rutile oxide alloys have the same or better thermodn. stability under operational conditions. By combining combinatorial compn., structure, and activity mapping with synchrotron X-ray absorption measurements and first-principles materials chem. calcns., a comprehensive understanding is provided of these oxide alloys and the crit. role is identified of Sb in stabilizing the trivalent Mn octahedra that have been shown to be effective oxygen evolution reaction (OER) catalysts.

Anion exchange membrane (AEM) electrolysis is a promising technol. to produce H through the splitting of pure H2O. In contrast to proton-exchange-membrane (PEM) technol., which requires precious-metal oxide anodes, AEM systems allow for the use of earth-abundant anode catalysts. Here the authors report a study of 1st-row transition-metal (oxy)hydroxide/oxide catalyst powders for application in AEM devices and compare phys. properties and performance to benchmark IrOx catalysts as well as typical catalysts for alk. electrolyzers. The catalysts' O-evolution activity measured in alk. electrolyte using a typical three-electrode cell is a poor indicator of performance in the AEM system. The best O-evolution-reaction (OER) catalysts in alk. electrolyte, NiFeOxHy oxyhydroxides, are the worst in AEM electrolysis devices where a solid alk. electrolyte was used along with a pure H2O feed. NiCoOx-based catalysts show the best performance in AEM electrolysis. The performance can be further improved by adding Fe species to the particle surface. The authors attribute the differences in performance in part to differences in the elec. cond. of the catalyst phases, which are also measured and reported.

A review. Bubbles are known to influence energy and mass transfer in gas-evolving electrodes. However, we lack a detailed understanding on the intricate dependencies between bubble evolution processes and electrochem. phenomena. This review discusses our current knowledge on the effects of bubbles on electrochem. systems with the aim to identify opportunities and motivate future research in this area. We first provide a base background on the physics of bubble evolution as it relates to electrochem. processes. Then we outline how bubbles affect energy efficiency of electrode processes, detailing the bubble-induced impacts on activation, ohmic, and concn. overpotentials. Lastly, we describe different strategies to mitigate losses and how to exploit bubbles to enhance electrochem. reactions.

Zero gap alk. electrolyzers hold the key to cheap and efficient renewable energy storage via the prodn. and distribution of hydrogen gas. A zero gap design, where porous electrodes are spacially sepd. only by the gas separator, allows the unique benefits of alk. electrolysis to be combined with the high efficiencies currently only assocd. with the more expensive PEM set-up. This review covers the basics of alk. electrolysis, and provides a detailed description of the advantages of employing a zero gap cell design over the traditional arrangement. A comparison with different types of zero gap cell designs currently seen in research is made, and a description of recent developments is presented. Finally, the current state of research into zero gap alk. electrolysis is discussed, and pathways for future research identified. Zero gap alk. electrolysis will allow excess renewable energy to be stored, transported and used on demand in a green and environmentally friendly manner as when the hydrogen is burnt or passed into a fuel cell it produces only water and energy.

The application of electrocatalysts with high activity to a practical water electrolysis cell is a crucial challenge for the prodn. of pure hydrogen and commercialization of the water electrolyzer. Herein, a nanosized Cu0.5Co2.5O4 catalyst synthesized by co-pptn. by adjusting pH is applied to the anion exchange membrane water electrolysis (AEMWE) cell as an anode, which is demonstrated to have higher efficiency and stability than noble metal-based anodes. The compn. (Cu/Co) and morphol. of Cu0.5Co2.5O4 change as the pH increases and then nanoparticles are formed at pH 11, where oxygen vacancies are formed by the etching of Cu. In the d. functional theory study, the electronic structure of Co modified by Cu in the Co3O4 lattice leads to an optimal adsorption strength, resulting in a free energy diagram in which the potential of Cu0.5Co2.5O4 (1.756 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode, RHE) is more thermodynamically favorable than that of Co3O4 (1.951 V vs. RHE). The Cu0.5Co2.5O4 catalyst has a recorded overpotential of 285 mV at 10 mA cm-2 in 1 M KOH. Furthermore, the AEMWE cell using Cu0.5Co2.5O4 as an anode exhibited a c.d. of 1.3 A cm-2 at 1.8 V, which is the highest performance among the reported papers and maintains around 80% energy conversion efficiency for 100 h.

A review. Water splitting is the essential chem. reaction to enable the storage of intermittent energies such as solar and wind in the form of hydrogen fuel. The oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is often considered as the bottleneck in water splitting. Though metal oxides had been reported as OER electrocatalysts more than half a century ago, the recent interest in renewable energy storage has spurred a renaissance of the studies of transition metal oxides as Earth-abundant and nonprecious OER catalysts. This Perspective presents major progress in several key areas of the field such as theor. understanding, activity trend, in situ and operando characterization, active site detn., and novel materials. A personal overview of the past achievements and future challenges is also provided.

Qin, Fan; Zhao, Zhenhuan; Alam, Md. Kamrul; Ni, Yizhou; Robles-Hernandez, Francisco; Yu, Luo; Chen, Shuo; Ren, Zhifeng; Wang, Zhiming; Bao, Jiming

We report the development of an efficient and earth-abundant catalyst for electrochem. overall water splitting. Trimetallic NiFeMo alloy is synthesized by hydrothermal deposition from inorg. precursors and subsequent low-temp. thermal annealing. A complete cell made of NiFeMo electrodes on nickel foam exhibits a low voltage of 1.45 V at 10 mA/cm2 as a result of low overpotentials for both hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). High-resoln. transmission electron microscopy reveals that nanometer-sized single-crystal domains of Ni, Fe, and Mo are intimately integrated at the at. level, which enables a synergistic effect of metallic Ni, Fe, and Mo for efficient HER, while self-formed Ni-Fe-Mo (oxy)hydroxides on the surface of the NiFeMo anode become active sites for OER. Such a multimetallic alloy and its (oxy)hydroxides represent a typical HER/OER catalyst couple, and our method provides a new route to develop efficient low-cost metallic alloys for overall water splitting.

A review on the fundamental and technol. issues relevant to H2O electrolysis in alk. and proton exchange membrane (PEM) devices is given. Due to price and limited availability of the Pt group metal (PGM) catalysts they currently employ, PEM electrolyzers have scant possibilities of being employed in large-scale H prodn. The importance and recent advancements in the development of catalysts without PGMs are poised to benefit more the field of alk. electrolysis rather than that of PEM devices. This paper presents the authors' original data which demonstrate that an advanced alk. electrolyzer with performances rivaling those of PEM electrolyzers can be made without PGM and with catalysts of high stability and durability. Studies on the advantages/limitations of electrolyzers with different architectures do show how a judicious application of pressure differentials in a recirculating electrolyte scheme helps reduce mass transport limitations, increasing efficiency and power d.

The sustainable electrochem. prodn. of hydrogen from water is a key element in the transition toward carbon-neutral energy systems. Application at a global scale requires the discovery of precious metal-free electrocatalysts that unify high energetic efficiency, long-term stability and economic viability. Here we report the striking properties of noble metal-free, alkali-metal cobalt borophosphates acting as robust and efficient materials for bi-functional electrocatalytic water-splitting to give hydrogen and oxygen. Alkali-metal cobalt borophosphates are porous cryst. inorg. materials with chiral DNA-like helical structures bearing two chem. distinct types of water mols., coordinated and strands of hydrate water assocd. via hydrogen bonds, located in the channels, which are predestined to possess superior catalytic performance. Depending on the applied electrode potential, they can be reversibly switched between catalysis of the hydrogen and oxygen evolution reactions, both at low overpotentials. This bifunctionality provides access to technol. simple overall water-splitting systems with energetic efficiencies exceeding the 75% level (above 90% based on a higher heating value) and uncompromised long-term stability, now verified with a two-and-a-half month period.

A review. Ionic sepn. and recombination processes in water electrolysis and fuel cell devices are of equal importance as the electron transfer processes that occur at the electrode surfaces. We illustrate the basic thermodn. concepts governing the flow of ions in electrolyzer and fuel cell systems and the effects of pH gradients on the electrochem. phenomena. Particularly, we focus on the use of bipolar membranes, which are composed of anion- and cation-selective membranes enabling operation with different pH environments at the anode vs. the cathode. The use of bipolar membranes thus broadens the materials' availability and could enable low-cost electrolysis systems that operate at very high efficiency. We end by discussing different materials and highlighting key gaps needed to realize such a system.

Water electrolysis has the potential to become a key element in coupling the electricity, mobility, heating and chem. sector via Power-to-Liqs. (PtL) or Power-to-Gas (PtG) in a future sustainable energy system. Based on an extensive market survey, discussions with manufacturers, project reports and literature, an overview of the current status of alk., PEM and solid oxide electrolysis on the way to large-scale flexible energy storage is presented. These main water electrolysis technologies were compared in terms of available capacity, nominal and part-load performance, flexibility (load range, load gradients, start-up time, stand-by losses) lifetime and investment costs. This review provides a basis of the parameters required and the necessary understanding of electrolysis fundamentals and technologies for a techno-economic anal. of water electrolysis-based concepts and an evaluation of PtG and PtL in energy system studies.

Here, we report a strategy using Fe substitution to enable the inactive spinel CoAl2O4 to become highly active and superior to the benchmark IrO2. It also activates deprotonation on the reconstructed oxyhydroxide to induce neg. charged oxygen as an active site, thus significantly enhancing the OER activity of CoAl2O4. Furthermore, it promotes the pre-oxidn. of Co and introduces great structural flexibility due to the uplift of the oxygen 2p levels. This results in the accumulation of surface oxygen vacancies along with lattice oxygen oxidn. that terminates as Al3+ leaches, preventing further reconstruction. We showcase a promising way to achieve tunable electrochem. reconstruction by optimizing the electronic structure for low-cost and robust spinel oxide OER catalysts.

Ba0.5Sr0.5Co0.8Fe0.2O3-δ (BSCF) catalyzes the OER with intrinsic activity that is at least an order of magnitude higher than that of the state-of-the-art Ir oxide catalyst in alk. media. The high activity of BSCF was predicted from a design principle established by systematic examn. of >10 transition metal oxides, which showed that the intrinsic OER activity exhibits a volcano-shaped dependence on the occupancy of the 3d electron with an eg symmetry of surface transition metal cations in an oxide. We report a type of NiCoFe layered triple hydroxides (LTHs) supported on carbon fiber cloth (CFC) (NiCoFe LTHs/CFC) as high-performance electrocatalysts for overall water splitting in alk. media. The NiCoFe LTHs/CFC as an oxygen evolution reaction (OER) electrocatalyst shows excellent catalytic activity and durability, such as low overpotential of ∼239 mV at 10 mA/cm2, small Tafel slope of ∼32 mV/dec and conservation rate of catalytic activity (∼99%) after 12 h of continuous electrolysis at 20 m/cm2. As a hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) electrocatalyst, NiCoFe LTHs/CFC also shows low onset potential, small Tafel slope, and superior durability. The NiCoFe LTHs/CFC-based overall water splitting exhibits a low onset potential (∼1.51 V), a low splitting potential (∼1.55 V) at 10 mA/cm2, and excellent durability, and the performance is comparable to that of IrO2/Pt-based overall water splitting. This work will open a new avenue toward the development of high-performance and inexpensive layered triple hydroxides electrocatalysts.

The oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is the performance-limiting half reaction of water splitting, which can be used to produce hydrogen fuel using renewable energies. Whereas a no. of transition metal oxides and oxyhydroxides have been developed as promising OER catalysts in alk. medium, the mechanisms of OER on these catalysts are not well understood. Here we combine electrochem. and in situ spectroscopic methods, particularly operando X-ray absorption and Raman spectroscopy, to study the mechanism of OER on cobalt oxyhydroxide (CoOOH), an archetypical unary OER catalyst. We find the dominating resting state of the catalyst as a Co(IV) species CoO2. Through oxygen isotope exchange expts., we discover a cobalt superoxide species as an active intermediate in the OER. This intermediate is formed concurrently to the oxidn. of CoOOH to CoO2. Combing spectroscopic and electrokinetic data, we identify the rate-detg. step of the OER as the release of dioxygen from the superoxide intermediate. The work provides important exptl. fingerprints and new mechanistic perspectives for OER catalysts.

A new electrochem. synthesis route was developed to prep. spinel-type ZnCo2O4 and Co3O4 as high quality thin film-type electrodes for use as electrocatalysts for oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Whereas Co3O4 contains Co2+ in the tetrahedral sites and Co3+ in the octahedral sites in the spinel structure, ZnCo2O4 contains only Co3+ in the octahedral sites; Co2+ in the tetrahedral sites is replaced by Zn2+. Therefore, by comparing the catalytic properties of ZnCo2O4 and Co3O4 electrodes prepd. with comparable surface morphologies and thicknesses, it was possible to examine whether Co2+ in Co3O4 is catalytically active for OER. The electrocatalytic properties of ZnCo2O4 and Co3O4 for OER in both 1 M KOH (pH 13.8) and 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7) solns. were investigated and compared. The results suggest that the Co2+ in Co3O4 is not catalytically crit. for OER and ZnCo2O4 can be a more economical and environmentally benign replacement for Co3O4 as an OER catalyst.
